title: Lesson B1-5 Assessment: Class IV (Indirect) Verbs

questions.question: What is the key characteristic of Class IV verbs?

options.text: Subject in Nominative, object in Dative
Experiencer in Dative, theme in Nominative
Both subject and object in Nominative
Subject in Dative, object in Genitive

questions.explanation: Class IV verbs use Dative-Nominative alignment: the experiencer (person who wants/knows/likes) takes Dative case, and the theme (thing experienced) takes Nominative case.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly expresses 'I want an apple'?
questions.explanation: In Class IV verbs, the theme (thing wanted) takes Nominative case. ვაშლი (vashli - apple) is in Nominative case, while ვაშლს is Dative, ვაშლის is Genitive, and ვაშლით is Instrumental.

questions.question: What does 'მომწონს (momts'ons)' mean?
questions.explanation: მომწონს (momts'ons) means 'I like' or literally 'it pleases me.' It comes from the verb მოწონება (to like/to please).

questions.question: In the sentence 'მე ვიცი ქართული (me vitsi kartuli - I know Georgian)', what case is 'მე (me - I)' in?
questions.explanation: In Class IV verbs like ცოდნა (to know), the experiencer 'მე' (I) takes Dative case, even though it appears as the subject in English. This is the key feature of Dative-Nominative alignment.

questions.question: Match the Georgian verb forms with their English translations:
questions.explanation: მინდა = I want (from უნდა), ვიცი = I know (from ცოდნა), მომწონს = I like (from მოწონება), ვსწავლობ = I study (from სწავლა).

questions.question: Which verb belongs to Class IV (Indirect verbs)?
questions.explanation: ვიცი (vitsi - I know) belongs to Class IV. The other verbs (ვხედავ, ვსაუბრობ, ვწერ) are Class I transitive verbs with Nominative-Dative alignment.

questions.question: What is the main difference between Class I and Class IV verbs?

options.text: Class I verbs use present tense, Class IV use past tense
Class I verbs have subject in Nominative and object in Dative; Class IV verbs have experiencer in Dative and theme in Nominative
Class I verbs are irregular, Class IV verbs are regular

questions.explanation: The key difference is in case alignment: Class I verbs follow Nominative-Dative (subject-object) pattern, while Class IV verbs follow Dative-Nominative (experiencer-theme) pattern. This reflects different semantic roles: doing vs. experiencing.

questions.question: Translate to Georgian: 'Do you (informal) know Georgian?'
questions.explanation: The correct translation is 'შენ იცი ქართული?' In Class IV verbs, the theme (thing known) takes Nominative case, so ქართული (kartuli - Georgian) is correct, not ქართულს (Dative) or ქართულის (Genitive).

questions.question: Which sentence is grammatically correct?

options.text: მას მოსწონს ეს ფილმი (mas mosts'ons es pilmi)
მას მოსწონს ეს ფილმს (mas mosts'ons es pilms)
მა მოსწონს ეს ფილმი (ma mosts'ons es pilmi)
მას მოსწონს ეს ფილმის (mas mosts'ons es pilmis)

questions.explanation: მას მოსწონს ეს ფილმი is correct. მას (mas - he/she) is in Dative case (experiencer), and ეს ფილმი (es pilmi - this film) is in Nominative case (theme).

questions.question: What does 'დატივ-ნომინატიური გათანაბრება (Dative-Nominative alignment)' mean in the context of Class IV verbs?

options.text: Both arguments are in the same case
The experiencer takes Dative case and the theme takes Nominative case
The verb agrees with both subject and object
The verb changes based on the tense

questions.explanation: Dative-Nominative alignment means that in Class IV verbs, the experiencer (person feeling/thinking) takes Dative case, while the theme (thing being experienced) takes Nominative case. This is the opposite pattern from Class I verbs.
